PageContent.Text: Hallo, Hi, Hola, Ola, Bonjour, Welcome…[br] to our new quiz

[div style='text-align:center']Safety in cyberspace…[br] Think no one can get one past you and that you’re up to speed on information security, FAKES, BLUFFS, and HACKS?…[br] After the intro, you can get started on our quiz straight away.[/div]
[div style='text-align:center; color:#E20074']Take a seat, relax and enjoy![/div]
[div style='text-align:center']Only a few steps lie between you, success, and your certificate[br] (at least 8 of 10 questions must be answered correctly)[/div]

[div style='text-align:center'] Don’t worry if you don’t pass. You can always try again![br] Or, you can brush up on YOUR KNOWLEDGE with these modules:[br] [span style='color:#E20074']“Protecting information and data” [/span] as well as [span style='color:#E20074']“Phishing“[/span] and [span style='color:#E20074']“Password security”[/span][/div]
[div style='text-align:center']So, now we can get started: [span style='color:#E20074']Let´s start …*[/span][/div]

[div style='text-align:center'] *If you come across an [img src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' style='width:40px' /] you can bring up more detailed information on the topic.[br]PLEASE USE FOR THE QUIZ OUR CURRENT INTERNET EXPLORER![br] Optimum screen resolution: 1680 x 1050 [/div]
Please choose your starting point:

PageContent.ButtonTo: You are a beginner? Then click here.
You are an expert? Then click here.

Variable.Text: Oops, unfortunately you didn’t quite do enough, or “play it again, Sam”*.[br] Here YOU can brush up on YOUR knowledge and then give it another go...[br] [span style='font-size:0.7em']*Quote from Hollywood classic “Casablanca”[/span][br][br] [span style='color:#E20074']The best security is the security that suits YOU.[/span]
Here you can start the 3 training modules and the quiz.[br] Feel ready? Then start the quiz.

PageContent.Text: [H3]"Information and personal data are like everyday objects – you ONLY share them if specific rules are OBSERVED."[/H3]

This comparison with everyday objects has been chosen deliberately in connection with security and data protection. Among other things, it should illustrate that handling information and personal data is an important part of our daily work.[br] [span style='color:#E20074']Would you lend someone your pen? [/span][br] You probably would. [br] [span style='color:#E20074']And what about your toothbrush?[/span][br] If at all, then only to people you know very well.
[H3]Information and data protection also work according to a very similar principle. [/H3]

Generally speaking, I keep my personal things "hidden", for example, in my toiletry bag – containers in which other personal items are kept in. And in the context of data protection and information security, [span style='color:#E20074']"confidential"[/span] items are also kept.[br] Before we look at "Classification" in more detail, however, we would like to explain what we mean by information and personal data, and what risks these are exposed to.
[H3]Are there differences between information and personal data?[/H3]

Yes. Personal data is information, but [span style='color:#E20074']information is not necessarily personal data[/span].[br] [span style='color:#E20074']Personal data[/span] is information about natural persons or information about a matter that can be linked to them. Examples of personal data include name, phone number, ID card number or bank account number.[br] [span style='color:#E20074']Personal data as defined by GDPR – European General Data Protection Regulation[/span] is always the data of a natural person, which means only data from natural persons is subject to data protection regulations.[br] In the broadest sense, [span style='color:#E20074']information[/span] refers to all knowledge about things or processes. Information which relates to internal company matters or our customers' affairs is generally referred to as company or business secrets. We also refer to such information as [span style='color:#E20074']business information[/span]. If the customers are public bodies, the data in question may be subject to secrecy.
[H3]Business information[/H3]

[span style='color:#E20074']Business information[/span] is all information that is [ul] [li]produced,[/li] [li]processed or [/li] [li]saved by the company.[/li] [/ul] Business information and personal data are encountered, for example, during day-to-day work on paper – printed or handwritten – in electronic (digital) or verbal form (face-to-face, via telephone, etc.).[br][br] Example of how to deal with this information: Confidential documents cannot simply be discussed over lunch unless it is ensured that only those colleagues who are authorized to receive the relevant information actually receive it.
[H3]What is the purpose of data and information protection and what is information security?[/H3]

While data protection protects individuals against the misuse of their personal data, information protection protects the business and trade secrets (business information) of our company.[br] The resulting protection level for information andvprotection can be referred to as information security and, for example, can also be certified as such.[br] Essentially, the aim is to ensure that so-called "protection objectives" are met.[br] The [span style='color:#E20074']four information security protection objectives[/span] are: [ul] [li][span style='color:#E20074']Confidentiality:[/span] Information is not made available or disclosed to unauthorized persons, units or processes.[/li] [li][span style='color:#E20074']Integrity:[/span] Safeguarding the accuracy and completeness of information.[/li] [li][span style='color:#E20074']Availability:[/span] Information is available to and can be used by authorized persons, systems or processes as necessary.[/li] [li][span style='color:#E20074']Authenticity:[/span] Evidence that the sender/originator and, where applicable, the recipient of an item of information are clearly verifiable.[/li] [/ul]
[H3]But why is the security of our information and personal data and their content so important to us?[/H3]

For interested parties to become customers and to ensure that they continue to have positive experiences, Deutsche Telekom is dependent on the protection of a large amount of business information and personal data. [br][br] [span style='color:#E20074']Company information and personal data represent existential values for Deutsche Telekom.[/span][br][br] They must therefore be protected against misuse and unauthorized disclosure.
[H3]And what does this have to do with me?[/H3]

The secure [span style='color:#E20074']processing[/span] of our customers' personal data, any disclosure of information, and also the [span style='color:#E20074']transmission[/span] of data are essential elements of our business. [br] The ability to adequately protect this data and information is therefore vital for us. All employees must help us to do this – that includes you! [span style='color:#E20074']Please always remember that you are obliged to maintain secrecy as part of your employment relationship.[/span]
[H3]What does information and data protection have to do with how our company is perceived?[/H3]

The Deutsche Telekom Group's [span style='color:#E20074']image[/span] is determined, among other things, by the actions of its employees.[br] Protecting our information and data is therefore also very important for reputation and image reasons. [br] If each employee protects business information and personal data against disclosure to unauthorized persons, this will help ensure that the company is seen in a positive light and protect it against possible damage.[br] After all, we are under constant scrutiny by the [span style='color:#E20074']media and the public[/span] when it comes to information and data protection.[br] [span style='color:#E20074']Customers and partners[/span] in particular must be able to rely on us dealing responsibly with their information.
[H3]What risks exist?[/H3]

We talk about an [span style='color:#E20074']information protection[/span] and/or a [span style='color:#E20074']data protection incident[/span] if, for example, ... [ul] [li]data or data storage media are stolen,[/li] [li]unauthorized third parties access customer data,[/li] [li]customer accounts are misused,[/li] [li]third parties gain access to information (e.g., espionage) or[/li] [li]company devices (e.g., laptops, tablets, smartphones) are lost.[/li] [/ul]
[H3]Where is business information and possibly personal data at risk of being lost?[/H3]

One can never be 100% sure that business information and personal data are protected against loss. Not even at the [span style='color:#E20074']workplace[/span]: For example, third parties who gain unauthorized access to our rooms can also access sensitive documents, files, data media or valuable items if an office is left unlocked or the items are not locked away.
[H3]Where is business information and possibly personal data at risk of being lost?[/H3]

[span style='color:#E20074']In meeting rooms[/span] (both at our company and on customers'/partners' premises): [ul] [li]If, for example, confidential documents are left lying around, or [/li] [li]the results of workshops with sensitive content are not removed from flip charts, or [/li] [li]confidential documents are disposed of by simply throwing them into the waste paper bin in the room.[/li] [/ul]
[H3]Where is business information and possibly personal data at risk of being lost?[/H3]

[span style='color:#E20074']In home offices[/span], e.g., in the event of a break-in or at [span style='color:#E20074']workstations[/span] in Telekom buildings if unauthorized third parties gain access.
[H3]Where is business information and possibly personal data at risk of being lost?[/H3]

[span style='color:#E20074']In public[/span], e.g., if employees, customers or confidential projects are mentioned, specifically in cafés, waiting areas or public transport when talking to colleagues on a mobile phone or face to face, or if third parties can see the contents of the screen on a mobile device.
[H3]Where is business information and possibly personal data at risk of being lost?[/H3]
[span style='color:#E20074']Outside the company[/span], e.g., during business trips if company documents or equipment is stolen or left lying in taxis, hotels, at railway stations or in airports.
[H3]Where is business information and possibly personal data at risk of being lost?[/H3]

[span style='color:#E20074']On social networks[/span], e.g., in excessively detailed profile descriptions or during discussions in own groups where people reveal too much information about their job, such as the names of other employees/customers or details of sensitive projects. [br] It is also important to ensure that no confidential documents or information is posted on internal company social networks such as [span style='color:#E20074']YAM[/span], in other words, the classification rules must be observed.
[H3]Who could harm our company with regard to our business information and personal data?[/H3]

Many competitors are keen to gain an insight into our [span style='color:#E20074']products, services, customer data[/span] or other [span style='color:#E20074'] insider knowledge[/span] about business-critical know-how. [br] Critical know-how can give competitors or other unauthorized third parties an advantage. This includes information about ...
[ul] [li]customers,[/li] [li]employees,[/li] [li]partners,[/li] [li]suppliers,[/li] [li]calculations or [/li] [li]product developments[/li] [/ul] The market for [span style='color:#E20074']economic crime[/span], in particular, often referred to in the media as "cyber crime", is becoming bigger and less manageable all the time. [br] At the same time, [span style='color:#E20074']intelligence agencies, hackers[/span] or [span style='color:#E20074']fraudsters[/span], e.g., "social engineers" are playing an increasingly important role.
[H3]Social engineering? What does that mean?[/H3]

Many [span style='color:#E20074']economic criminals[/span] have the skills needed to make people talk through [span style='color:#E20074']social manipulation[/span].[br] Their aim is to gain in-depth insights into companies, e.g., in order to obtain and possibly sell business-critical know-how. [br] These skills are referred to as "social engineering". [br] "Social" means that people are essentially "hacked" and reveal information that can be used by third parties against their will in discussions. This information can include
[ul] [li]the boss's [span style='color:#E20074']telephone number[/span] [/li] [li]our [span style='color:#E20074']customer data[/span] (especially data relating to known or important persons) or [/li] [li]details of [span style='color:#E20074']concepts, figures, acquisitions[/span] that have not yet been published.[/li] [/ul]
[H3]Are there other more specific examples?[/H3]

Yes, there are lots of examples – also from our immediate surroundings.[br][br] Example 1: T-Online hack[br] In August 2015, hackers gained access to the e-mail address books of thousands of T-Online customers. They used the data they obtained to send e-mails to the acquaintances of the affected users in their name. [br] The messages were sent in the name of the hacked T-Online customers with subject lines such as "FW: Important" or "try it out". They contained a link which, if clicked on, installed malware.
[H3]Example 2:[/H3]

Foreign scientists spent months disguised as cleaners at a large chemicals group. During nighttime cleaning, they were able to search offices and laboratories undisturbed.[br] The risks here were not only [span style='color:#E20074']desks[/span] on which business information and personal data "spend the night" but also [span style='color:#E20074']waste paper bins[/span] where documents are discarded instead of being disposed of securely in a special data bin or shredder. [br] Rummaging through waste paper bins is also known as [span style='color:#E20074']"dumpster diving"[/span].
[H3][span lang='en']Clear Desk[/span][/H3]

This is why the idea of the [span style='color:#E20074']"clear desk"[/span] is so important when it comes to information and data protection and information security.[br] However, "clear desk" is not just about locking away confidential information and data when leaving workstations and meeting rooms. In a broader sense, it also means securely [span style='color:#E20074']deleting or disposing of documents[/span] and data media that are no longer needed.
[H3]Does all information really need to be protected? [/H3]

Yes and no. With the help of [span style='color:#E20074']information, we communicate[/span] with customers, partners or the media for example. [br] The information and data that they receive from us are therefore potentially in the public domain.[br] [span style='color:#E20074']However, WE want to decide what information is public and what is not.[/span][br] Because sensitive and less sensitive business information and personal data exist, it is important for you as an employee to [span style='color:#E20074'] distinguish[/span] between documents, information and data that need to be protected and those that do not.[br] In this context, we refer to the [span style='color:#E20074']"protection requirement"[/span] that apply to the information or the personal data.[br] With the help of our [span style='color:#E20074']rules and recommendations[/span], we would like to ensure that all employees can handle all business information and personal data in an appropriate, standardized manner.
[H3]How are protection requirements determined?[/H3]

In order to be able to define and put in place the necessary degree of protection, information and personal data must [span style='color:#E20074']be classified in a standardized manner[/span] throughout the company. [br] The Deutsche Telekom Group has therefore defined the following [span style='color:#E20074']two protection classes[/span] under which all sensitive information can be classified: [ul] [li]INTERNAL[/li] [li]CONFIDENTIAL[/li] [/ul] The previously used protection class „strictly confidential“ has been dropped[span style='color:#E20074']*[/span]. Information that was previously marked as „strictly confidential“ is now included in the „CONFIDENTIAL“ protection class.[br] Please note: When working with public clients, it may be necessary to handle classified information (state secrets). These classified projects or activities are subject to additional regulations. The Group's classification organization can answer any questions regarding these regulations.[br] [span style='color:#E20074']*Not for T-Systems: Valid from January 1, 2019 [/span]
[H3]How are business and personal information classified according to their protection needs?[/H3]

When classifying, the answer to two simple questions simplifies the assignment to a protection class:[br][br] [ol] [li][span style='color:#E20074']May the information be made public?[/span][br] If you answer this question with “YES”, this is an information that may be made public. If your answer is “NO”, it is information at least the [span style='color:#E20074']INTERNAL[/span] protection class. In this case you also have to answer the second question.[/li] [li][span style='color:#E20074']Is everyone in the Group allowed to know?[/span][br] If your answer this question with “YES”, this is information of the protection class [span style='color:#E20074']INTERNAL[/span]. If your answer is [span style='color:#E20074']“NO”[/span], the information is [span style='color:#E20074']CONFIDENTIAL[/span].[/li] [/ol]
[H3]Classification examples for the protection classes „internal“ and „confidential“, everything else is public[/H3]

[ul] [li][span style='color:#E20074']INTERNAL[/span][/li] [ul] [li]Business [span style='color:#E20074']information[/span] which, if disclosed to unauthorized persons, could lead to financial losses or image damage.[/li] [li][span style='color:#E20074']Personal data with low protection requirments[/span], e.g. business contact details of an employee, personal data that is pseudonymized.[/li] [/ul] [li style='margin-top:20px'][span style='color:#E20074']CONFIDENTIAL[/span][/li] [ul] [li]Business [span style='color:#E20074']information[/span] which, if disclosed to unauthorized persons, could leat to financial losses, e.g., audit reports, security concepts, draft contracts with high volumes, financial and sales figures, board templates.[/li] [li][span style='color:#E20074']Personal data with high protection requirements[/span], e.g., private addresses of customers, account numbers, dates of birth, salary data.[/li] [/ul] [/ul]
[H3]Do I also need to be able to distinguish between types of information?[/H3]

Yes. Anyone who produces information must also be able to assign it to one of the four protection classes. [br] In the case of the [span style='color:#E20074']CONFIDENTIAL[/span] protection classes, the protection class must be clearly indicated, e.g., through details in the footer of the relevant document.[br] Only if the recipient knows the classification can he/she be certain about how to deal with such an information. [br] If you receive information which is not labeled, you have to categorize it at least as [span style='color:#E20074']INTERNAL[/span] in case of doubt.
[H3]Do I also need to be able to distinguish between types of information?[/H3]

ALL information must be protected according to its classification – regardless of what form it is in.[br] [span style='color:#E20074']EVERY employee is obliged to protect information, in other words, for every item of information requiring protection, there must be someone who is responsible for adequately protecting it.[/span] Generally speaking, this is primarily the author of the relevant information followed by each person who handles it.[br] Confidential information must always be [span style='color:#E20074']encrypted[/span] before being transferred or stored. When passing information on, the pricniple of „Need-to-know“ must always be observed. Confidential paper documents should be locked away after use.
[H3]In the previous chapters, you were confronted with numerous basic rules regarding information security and data protection, some of which may be new to you.[/H3]

The [span style='color:#E20074']aim[/span] of the training course is to ensure that you are familiar with these [span style='color:#E20074']5 rules of thumb[/span] and can apply them.[br] Please make a good mental note of them and be sure to apply them at all times.

[ul] [li]I am personally responsible for protecting all personal data and business information in my working environment. [/li] [li]As the author, I always classify the business information in one of protection classes ("INTERNAL“ or "CONFIDENTIAL") – regardless of whether this information is in paper, digital or other form – and label confidential information as such. [/li] [li]always handle information that I produce myself or receive in accordance with the relevant protection requirements. [/li] [li]considerably contribute to protecting business and personal information and do not disclose it in public privately.[/li] [li]report significant information protection and/or data protection incidents using the following telephone numbers and e-mail addresses: +49 800 9900077,[br] konzernlagezentrum@telekom.de (KLZ) oder[br] +49 800 3304 006, datenschutz@telekom.de[/li] [/ul]

Page.powered: [table][tr][td][img src='pInfosicherheit/Images/Logo_2.png' height='29' alt='' /] [/td][td] powered by Telekom Security[/td][/tr][/table]

PageContent.Text: HELLO, GREAT TO HAVE YOU[br]HERE @PHISHING
PHISHING
In this module, YOU will learn the following in a clearly understandable way:
All the important things to know about phishing.
Then YOU will be able to make practical use of everything YOU have learned in YOUR digital life.
'FISCHER’S FRITZ[br] FISHES FOR FRESH FISH,[br] FRESH FISH[br] IS FISHED BY FISCHER’S FRITZ, FISHING[br] FOR PINS AND TANS'

Theft of login details for online services is one of the most frequent crimes committed by cybercriminals. In the worst cases, they can access bank details, PIN codes, or credit card information, which can lead to financial losses for their victims.[br][br] The starting point for such phishing attacks are usually specially created emails.[br][br] [span style='color:#E20074']We’ll show YOU what we mean...[/span][br][br]
WHAT IS PHISHING?
Phishing is a form of cyberattack whereby thieves use fake emails, text messages, or websites to obtain confidential login and identification details from internet users, or other similar data.

The term [span style='color:#E20074']„Phishing“[/span] comes from the “p” in [span style='color:#E20074']Password[/span] plus the word [span style='color:#E20074']„fishing“[/span].[br] In short, it means using bait to fish for passwords.
WHAT IS PHISHING?
The danger of phishing attacks can be lurking anywhere on the internet at any time. Phishing emails end up in the inboxes of millions of internet users almost every day.
Phishers are often responsible for targeted internet attacks. They utilize sophisticated techniques and exploit the information that they gain for various purposes.
TYPICAL TARGETS OF PHISHING ATTACKS INCLUDE:

[ul] [li]Login details for online banking accounts, credit card information, transaction numbers and PINs, etc.[/li] [li]Passwords for email accounts and login details for websites for online auctions or social networks (social phishing).[/li] [/ul]
POSSIBLE REASONS FOR PHISHING:

[ul] [li]One example is online application letters, known as CEO fraud. To pillage bank accounts or commit credit card fraud[/li] [li]To order goods from online retailers under a false name[/li] [li]To attack companies, gain unauthorized access to and use their IT systems, or obtain money or objects by other fraudulent means[/li] [li]To sell data on to third parties, such as operators of botnets*[/li] [/ul] [span style='font-size:0.7em']*A [b]botnet[/b] * is a group of automated malicious programs, known as bots. The bots (from “robot”) run on networked computers, within which they have access to the network connection and local resources and data without the owner’s knowledge.[/span]
TYPICAL PHISHING EMAILS:

[ul] [li]Fake bank emails[/li] [li]Supposed SEPA messages[/li] [li]Fictitious notifications of winnings from gambling games or free prize giveaways[/li] [li]Fake invoices from IT or payment service providers or online retailers[/li] [li]Fake confirmations of supposed orders, or fake payment reminders[/li] [li]Fake messages about data privacy policies or terms and conditions to be accepted[/li] [/ul]
WHAT TECHNIQUES DO PHISHERS USE?

[table style='width:100%'] [tr] [td style='width:90%'] [b][span style='color:#E20074']IMPERSONATION:[/span][/b] Cybercriminals impersonating real banks or companies encourage the recipients of phishing emails to update their details. [/td] [td style='width:10%; text-align:right'] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(1)' style='width:50px' /] [/td] [/tr] [tr] [td style='width:90%'] [b][span style='color:#E20074']SPOOFING[/span][/b]: Phishing emails are designed to be deceptively similar to the original emails. [/td] [td style='width:10%; text-align:right'] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(2)' style='width:50px' /] [/td] [/tr] [tr] [td style='width:90%'] [b][span style='color:#E20074']DECEPTION[/span][/b]: The recipient receives a phishing email in which they are prompted to fill out a form or click on a link and enter their login details. [/td] [td style='width:10%; text-align:right'] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(3)' style='width:50px'/] [/td] [/tr] [/table]

PageContent.Dialog: The email might say:[br] “Your credit card has expired,”[br] “Your account has been temporarily blocked,” or[br] "Please confirm your new login details"
The layout (corporate design), sender address, or direct customer greeting may make them look as though they could well have come from a bank, online retailer, or other service provider.
Emails in HTML format lead the recipient directly to an “official” link, but this link contains a hidden, completely different, link.

PageContent.Text: WHAT TECHNIQUES DO PHISHERS USE?

[table style='width:100%'] [tr] [td style='width:90%'] [b][span style='color:#E20074']TRAPS:[/span][/b] Here, the phisher sends a link that leads to a fake login page created by the attacker. This page looks almost identical to the original page on the online platform.[br] [/td] [td style='width:10%; text-align:right'] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(4)' style='width:50px' /] [/td] [/tr] [tr] [td style='width:90%'] [b][span style='color:#E20074']PHISHING:[/span][/b] : If the recipient believes the email to be authentic and enters their details into the fake website, they fall into the trap. [/td] [td style='width:10%; text-align:right'] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(5)' style='width:50px' /] [/td] [/tr] [/table]

PageContent.Dialog: Even the user interface looks the same. The victim sees a seemingly secure environment, which is actually fake.
The phisher then has their details and can use the person’s identity information online.

PageContent.Text: WARNING!
[span style='color:#E20074']Phishing fraudsters[/span] often use internet addresses which only differ very slightly from the original address.

With [span style='color:#E20074']Spoofing*[/span] the phisher may use umlauts in German to create false URLs. For example, original addresses like [b]http://www.aktionaersbank.de[/b] can be impersonated with an address like [b]http://www.aktionaer-bank.de[/b].

Phishers may also integrate [b]malware**[/b] such as viruses or trojans as a link, attachment, or email source code in HTML format in their emails. Just clicking on an image in a phishing email can have severe consequences.

[div style='font-size:0.7em; line-height:0.9em '] [table style='width:100%'] [tr] [td valign='top'] * [/td] [td]Spoofing is the term used in information technology for various deceptive methods used in computer networks to disguise one’s identity. [br][br] [/td] [/tr] [tr] [td] ** [/td] [td]Computer programs developed to perform unwanted, and often harmful, functions. [/td] [/tr] [/table] [/div]
WARNING!

[span style='color:#E20074']Emails [/span] are not the only way to phish. Victims may also be targeted through. [b]SMS[/b] or [b]QR[/b] codes with links to fake websites, in social networks, in digital telephone services (vishing), or in LinkedIn, WhatsApp, or Skype.

Ein [span style='color:#E20074']A trojan attack[/span] can even influence the operating system’s host file in such a way that the user is automatically forwarded to the criminal’s fake website. If the victim now enters their bank's website address, they will end up on the phishing website.
YOU CAN PROTECT YOURSELF USING A PHISHING CHECK:

[span style='color:#E20074']FAKE SENDER ADDRESS[/span][br] Click on the sender’s address: Does the email address that you see contain suspicious elements? Are there spelling mistakes in the address, even minor ones?

[span style='color:#E20074']REQUEST FOR CONFIDENTIAL DATA[/span][br] Does the link embedded in the email prompt you to enter personal data? Are secret numbers such as PINs, TANs, or passwords requested?
YOU CAN PROTECT YOURSELF USING A PHISHING CHECK:

[table style='width:100%'] [tr] [td style='width:90%'] [span style='color:#E20074']URGENCY[/span][br] Does the email encourage you to act immediately? Does it contain a threat? [/td] [td style='width:10%; text-align:right']
[/td] [/tr] [/table]

[table style='width:100%'] [tr] [td style='width:90%'] [span style='color:#E20074']LINKS TO FAKE WEBSITES[/span][br] What target URL appears when you hover over the link with your mouse? Is the target page safe (the URL should begin with "https://") and encrypted (padlock symbol by the URL)? [/td] [td style='width:10%; text-align:right'] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(6)' style='width:50px' /] [/td] [/tr] [/table]

[table style='width:100%'] [tr] [td style='width:90%'] [span style='color:#E20074']STRANGE FORMULATIONS[/span][br] Is the greeting in the email impersonal? Does the text contain spelling mistakes, improper punctuation, or special characters? [br] More on RULES FOR PROTECTING YOURSELF AGAINST PHISHING ATTACKS [/td] [td style='width:10%; text-align:right'] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(7)' style='width:50px' /] [/td] [/tr] [/table]

PageContent.Dialog: [span style='font-size:15px'][ul] [li]Never confirm your account number, passwords, or other secret information when requested to do so by email! Real banks or companies would never use this method, for security reasons![/li] [li]If an online payment system or online retailer like PayPal, Amazon, or eBay prompts you to update your details, enter the website address manually in your browser’s address bar. Never use an email link.[/li] [li]Check the security status of websites before entering personal data! HTTPS does not guarantee that a website is genuine. Click on the padlock symbol displayed by the URL in your browser to check the website’s security certificate.[/li] [li]If you receive an email from an unknown sender, only open any links, forms, or attachments that they have sent once you have checked them, for example by hovering over them with your mouse or checking them with CERT before continuing.[/li] [/ul][/span]

[span style='font-size:15px'][ul] [li]If you receive a suspicious email from a trustworthy sender, like your bank, it is best to contact them by telephone to confirm that the email is genuine.[/li] [li]Phishers can exploit security weaknesses in programs, particularly browsers. Update your browser software regularly, and always install the latest updates.[/li] [li]In your private life, use the latest antivirus programs, firewalls, and web filters, and flag unwanted emails as spam, or delete them![/li] [li]Use different passwords for your work and private accounts.[/li] [li]If you suspect that you have fallen victim to a phishing attack, inform CERT@telekom.de (at work) and your bank or business partners (at home) straight away, and change your login details immediately.[/li] [li]Trusting in the infallibility of technology can leave the door open to phishing attacks. A healthy level of mistrust prevents phishers from stealing your identity and gaining access to your accounts and IT systems![/li] [/ul][/span]

PageContent.Text: GREAT, YOU DID IT!
You can now put what you have learned into practice.

Page.powered: [table][tr][td][img src='pInfosicherheit/Images/Logo_2.png' height='29' alt='' /] [/td][td] powered by Telekom Security[/td][/tr][/table]

PageContent.Text: HELLO, GREAT TO HAVE YOU[br]HERE @PASSWORD SECURITY
PASSWORD SECURITY
In this module, you will learn the following in a clearly understandable way:
All the important things to know about passwords.
Protecting your passwords is protecting yourself: It stops things from happening without your consent!
Then you will be able to make practical use of everything you have learned in YOUR digital life.
PASSWORD SECURITY
Poorly chosen passwords are right at the top of the hit list of most common IT security deficits.

Too many people are still using passwords like “123456,” “Password,” or easy-to-guess names. Those that have made the effort to choose a secure password often use it for lots of different IT systems and internet applications. Of course, hackers are delighted about this. They have tools that automatically try out all possible character combinations or access data (e.g., rainbow tables or allocation of hash values) published online for various services.
To prevent this, a password should meet certain quality requirements.[br] [span style='color:#E20074']We’ll show YOU what WE mean...[/span]
ACCESS CONTROL

[table style='width:100%'] [tr] [td style='width:90%'] [span style='color:#E20074']Strong passwords[/span] are an absolute must throughout the digital world – here at the Deutsche Telekom Group as well as at home.[br] Access control is a prerequisite for ensuring information security in IT. The objectives of access control are defined in Deutsche Telekom’s security policy. [/td] [td style='width:10%; text-align:right'] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(8)' style='width:50px' /] [/td] [/tr] [/table] [br] Link: [a href='https://richtlinien.telekom.de/ridb/RM/de/mrdetail?MRPosFromSearchListAndCover=2&mrNummer=50' target='_blank']Policy/Policies Database[/a]

PageContent.Dialog: [b]security policy:[/b][br] Limiting access to information and information processing facilities in line with Deutsche Telekom’s business requirements. Granting access exclusively to authorized users and preventing unauthorized access to Deutsche Telekom's IT systems, data storage, and IT services. Preventing unauthorized access to Deutsche Telekom's systems and applications.

PageContent.Text: ACCESS CONTROL
[div style='text-align:center; color:#E20074']YOU are responsible for protecting your authentication details and tokens, including password protection![/div]

[ul] [li]Authentication details and tokens must be treated as confidential, and stored securely, if stored at all.[/li] [li]Passing them onto other people – even IT technicians or managers – is strictly forbidden.[/li] [li]Change your passwords regularly, particularly if you suspect that someone might know them.[/li] [/ul]
PASSWORDS
[span style='color:#E20074']The assignment and activation of passwords have become EASIER + MORE SECURE with the change in the password rule.[/span]

[ul] [li]The new password must be made up of at least twelve characters of a complex character set (characters from three of the following four groups must be included): upper case letter, lower case letter, number, special character.[/li] [/ul] [ul] [li]The new password is valid for 365 days.[/li] [/ul] [ul] [li]Once the password has been entered incorrectly five times, the Windows account (A account) will be blocked.[/li] [/ul]

(This rule applies only to DT workstation systems and mobile devices and is successively implemented with major releases. The policy for IT systems (8 characters, validity 3 months) remains in force.)
BASIC RULES* FOR HANDLING PASSWORDS

[table style='width:100%'] [tr] [td style='width:90%'] [ul] [li]Use strong passwords. The longer and more complex a password is, the more difficult it is to crack.[/li] [li]Use a different password for each IT application and internet service. [/li] [li]Work and private passwords must be different.[/li] [li]Passwords must never be stored unencrypted on a PC or in a smartphone phone book, or written on a Post-it note and attached to a PC or external keyboard.[/li] [li]It is better to use a password manager (e.g., KeePass) to manage your passwords.[/li] [/ul] [/td] [td style='width:10%; text-align:right'] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(9)' style='width:50px' /][br] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(10)' style='width:50px' /][br] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(11)' style='width:50px' /] [/td] [/tr] [/table] [br][br] * Please observe for private and/or work applications where recommended and available.

PageContent.Dialog: [b]TIP: A selection of different character sets [/b] (letters + numbers + special characters) increases the number of possible character combinations. This makes it more difficult for hackers to crack a password, however they can use the “brute force method” to crack any password. It's just a matter of time.

[b]Special requirements apply for the encryption of documents or files[/b] (e.g., Secure File or WinZip or Adobe Acrobat, ….). Please observe the applicable regulations or recommendations. For encryption methods for WLAN, such as WPA and WPA2, the password should be as long as possible.

[b]Secure passwords can be generated and stored in an encrypted database, for instance[/b]. To ensure that only you can access the password list, secure the database with a master password. Then you only need to remember the master password. This is particularly important for all passwords used within Deutsche Telekom’s company network, including passwords for using systems and applications.

PageContent.Text: BASIC RULES* FOR HANDLING PASSWORDS

[table style='width:100%'] [tr] [td style='width:90%'] [ul] [li]Where possible, use the [b]two-factor authentication option[/b].[/li] [li]To protect against password theft (e.g., using a keylogger), always keep the software on your PC and other IT devices [b]up to date[/b].[/li] [/ul] [/td] [td style='width:10%; text-align:right'] [input class='SmileyInput' type='image' src='pInfosicherheit/Images/__Imogy.png' onClick='showDialog(12)' style='width:50px' /] [/td] [/tr] [/table]

PageContent.Dialog: In addition to entering your password, log in using a personal confirmation code, for example through your smartphone. This prevents hackers being able to log into accounts, even if they know your password.

PageContent.Text: TIP: USE A PASSPHRASE

The advantages of a passphrase: [ul] [li]Greater security than a complicated password.[/li] [li]It can have 100 characters or more and can also contain spaces.[/li] [li]It can be made up of a sequence of words and terms.[/li] [li]Well-known quotes or lines from famous pop songs are not suitable as many hacking programs contain collections of quotes.[/li] [li]Better passphrases are phrases that YOU thought up YOURSELF – possibly even nonsense phrases.[/li] [/ul] You will find examples on our YAM site, on the “16 minutes” page under Security Awareness.[br][br] * Please observe for private and/or work applications where recommended and available.
GREAT, YOU DID IT! CONGRATULATIONS!!!
Now put what you have learned into practice.
Brilliant, you have passed the information security quiz! Congratulations from the Security Awareness team!!!
You can now use what you have learned in practice.

[center] Stay informed and follow this group:[br] [a href='https://yam.telekom.de/groups/telekom-security-awareness-produkte/pages/english' target='_blank' title='Security Awareness'][img src='pInfosicherheit/Images/Link1.png' style='height:80px; margin-left:3% ' /][/a] [br] [span style='color:#E20074; font-size:1.4em; font-weight:700']Be Aw[span class='copyleft']ra[/span]e - Be Secure[/span] [/center]
[br] [a href='pInfosicherheit/XML/FINAL_Handout_Quiz_EN_V04.pdf' target='_blank' title='Handout'] [img src='pInfosicherheit/Images/Link5.png' style='height:80px; margin-left:3%' /][/a]

6 Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consetetur sadipscing elitr, sed diam nonumy eirmod tempor invidunt ut labore et dolore magna aliquyam erat, sed diam voluptua. At vero eos et accusam et justo duo dolores et ea rebum. Stet clita kasd gubergren, no sea takimata sanctus est Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.

7 Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consetetur sadipscing elitr, sed diam nonumy eirmod tempor invidunt ut labore et dolore magna aliquyam erat, sed diam voluptua. At vero eos et accusam et justo duo dolores et ea rebum. Stet clita kasd gubergren, no sea takimata sanctus est Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.

Question.QuestionText: What do you understand by information security? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: Protection of business and trade secrets
According to their importance, information and data are requiring a defined protection level.
Information security protects business information and protects personal data against misuse.

Question.QuestionText: Which protection goals of information security do you know? (Multiple answers are possible)
Which protection goals of information security do you know? (Multiple answers are possible)
Why does Deutsche Telekom Group need to protect customers’ business information and personal data? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: They are of existential value to Deutsche Telekom.
All prospective buyers and customers should associate Deutsche Telekom with only positive experiences.
The customers’ data and information are the essential asset of our company.
It allows DTAG to increase the size of their data lake for future use. All companies pay attention to the confidentiality of their customer- and employee data.

Question.QuestionText: What is the purpose of information and data protection?
Question.Answer: The protection of business information and the protection of individuals against misuse of their personal data.
The protection of individuals against misuse of their personal data.
The protection of business information against misuse of personal data.

Question.QuestionText: What are the potential risks for information? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: Theft of data and data media
Loss of mobile devices (laptops, cell phones, tablets, etc.)
Misuse of customer accounts and customer data

Question.QuestionText: What are the potential risks for information? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: Third parties gaining access to information (e.g., through social engineering)
The loss of business used devices

Question.QuestionText: Where is business information and personal data at risk of being lost? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: Never, because all devices are password protected

Question.QuestionText: Where is business information and personal data at risk of being lost? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: In the workplace (e.g., desk sharing, etc.)

Question.QuestionText: Who could be interested in harming the Deutsche Telekom Group? (Multiple answers are possible)
Who could be interested in harming the Deutsche Telekom Group? (Multiple answers are possible)
What does social engineering mean?
Question.Answer: Hackers have skills that enable them to gather confidential data.
Criminals exploit and encourage people to act in a way, the criminal wishes through social manipulation.
Trained individuals have skills that enable them to steal business IT devices.

Question.QuestionText: What should I do if I realize afterwards that I have passed on potentially confidential information to unauthorized third parties ?
Question.Answer: Post a warning only on YAM that social engineers (SE) are out and about.
Inform only your own colleagues about it.
Document the conversation with the social engineer (SE), check their identity (if possible), report the incident to your manager.

Question.QuestionText: What is the name of an “impersonal” variant of social engineering?
As regards the classification of information, what protection classes do you know?
As regards the classification of information, what protection classes do you know? (Multiple answers are possible)
What protection classes do you know? (Multiple answers are possible)

Questions.Question: 0 5:10:50 How many universal protection classes are valid to the information classification system in the group Deutsche Telekom? 3 4 5 or more> Images/Fragezeichen3.jpg

Question.QuestionText: What kind of information needs to be protected? (Multiple answers are possible)
What kind of information needs to be protected? (Multiple answers are possible)
What is phishing? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: Phishing scams “use baits to fish for passwords”.
Phishing refers to cyberattacks by perpetrators who use fake emails, text messages, or websites to acquire internet users' confidential login and identification details.
Phishing refers to industrial espionage where confidential documents, for instance, are stolen from the trash folder.

Question.QuestionText: What methods are used in phishing attacks? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: Bulk email sending with fake content that is harmful to computers.
Fake Websites whose URL is only barely different from the original URL.
Text messages with a fake bait.

Question.QuestionText: What methods are used in phishing attacks? (Multiple answers possible)
Question.Answer: QR codes with links to fake websites.
Personal and encrypted data are decrypted.

Question.QuestionText: How can you stop being exploited by phishing emails? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: Check sender addresses carefully (trueness and notation).
When asked for confidential data, check carefully whether the recipient is authorized.
There is nothing I can do. There is no need to check anything because computers are protected by a firewall.

Question.QuestionText: How can you stop being exploited by phishing emails? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: Consider whether this is a real priority or whether a threat is made – do you feel comfortable?
For email links, first carry out the "Mouse over" test to see whether the target URL contains puzzling information.
Check the text of the email for spelling mistakes or incorrect characters and the type of salutation used (personal/impersonal).
Deactivate the internet access for ever.

Question.QuestionText: What warning signs help you to recognize a phishing email? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: The sender puts pressure on you.
Direct request to enter personal data once again in an extra e-mail.

Question.QuestionText: What warning signs help you to recognize a phishing email? (Multiple answers are possible)
What organizations do hackers like to use for Phishing attacks? (Multiple answers are possible)
What organizations do hackers like to use for Phishing attacks? (Multiple answers are possible)
What does a Windows password look like according to the current password policy?
Question.Answer: A Windows password should have at least 12 characters and consist of at least three of the four categories (upper / lower case letters, numbers, special characters).
A Windows password should have at least 7 letters (small / large) and a special character or number.
A Windows password should have at least 8 characters and consist two of the capital letters and numbers.

Question.QuestionText: What passwords are currently considered to be “strong passwords”?
What passwords are currently considered to be “strong passwords”?
Who is responsible for the protection of authentication information, including password protection?
How are the means of authentication to be used?
Question.Answer: They are only to be used personally and individually.
They are put together in a document for quick access.

Question.QuestionText: How are the means of authentication to be used? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: It is not allowed to pass the means of authentication on or disclose them to anyone else.
The validity of the means of authentication must be time limited.
Certificates and passwords are to be used individually and never by groups of people.

Question.QuestionText: Which basic rules for handling passwords are correct?
Question.Answer: If you create a complex password it can be used in different tools.
You can store your passwords unencrypted on your PC.

Question.QuestionText: Which basic rules for handling passwords are correct? (Multiple answers are possible)
Question.Answer: Change your passwords as described in the password policy.
You can use a password manager to manage your passwords.
If possible, use the two-factor authentication option.
Store your password under your office desk pad.
